reviewText: To be honest "as much as I would like it", I can't afford the Complete Series Set of Thriller...But this is a Great set to start with till I can afford the Complete Series Set...There are some Great Classics in this set such as THE GRIM REAPER, THE CHEATERS, THE HUNGRY GLASS & The one I remember seeing as a child on T.V. THE WEIRD TAILOR .... As well as other classics in this set. The picture & sound quality is great. However please note that I'm viewing this using a regular "Non HD" television , so the opinion on the video & sound quality may differ with someone using more high end audio & video systems ... As for me, I LOVE IT .... Bob

reviewText: Some of these stories were exactly how I remembered them, although the episode The Watcher was very substandard and Well of Doom was poor compared to most of the others. But episodes: The Grim Reaper, The Hungry Glass and The Incredible Dr Markesan made such an indelible mark on me that I still remember certain scenes after all these years.I've often wondered where Chrissie Hynde got the most unusual lyric "Got in the house like a pigeon from hell" (Back on the Chain Gang) I understand Meatloaf's "Bat" out of Hell but a "Pigeon" come on, and then I watched the episode on here it became very clear she must have seen it too.~~~~Two discs.The Grim ReaperPigeons from HellThe WatcherThe Hungry GlassThe Cheaters - Good story, a reworking from the Wilkie Collins story "The Devil's Spectacles".The Incredible Dr. Markesan - when I was eight the last scene of this episode scared me for many years! my favourite.The Weird TailorThe Purple RoomThe Prisoner in the MirrorWell of Doom~~~~If you liked this you may like "The Veil" another show introduced by Boris from a few years earlier. Which was never released!Overall verdict, if you like 'em old and creepy and in glorious black and white this is your next purchase.
summary: Got in the House like a Pigeon from Hell.

reviewText: I remember gathering in front of the TV set with my family to watch this series so I was glad to see that Amazon had the Thriller fan Favorites collection. Boris Karloff hosted the show and had roles in a few of the episodes.  Boris would begin several of the episodes saying in an eerie voice "this will be a thriller sure as my name is Boris Karloff". Most of the episodes still hold up well.

reviewText: Classier and more spine-tingling than Twilight Zone or One Step Beyond - but it ran for only two seasons.  In my opinion, these constitute a very good selection, with "The Hungry Glass" and "The Grim Reaper" as standouts (both have William Shatner as the lead); only "Terror in Teakwood" (the story made in 1946 into the full-length movie, "The Beast with Five Fingers," with Peter Lorre), is an omitted gem.  There are other episodes which, while not of the best "Auslese," are still mighty good, if you are willing to spend for the complete set.PS The episode of "Terror in Teakwood" can be gotten separately as a VHS tape.

reviewText: THRILLER!  Before there was Lost in Space, before The Outer Limits, before The Twilight Zone, there was THRILLER.  This show sheds some light on "early suspense/creepiness" on TV. Pretty-mild by today's standards but some interesting plots and fun to watch. It was popular in its time. Glad I have it.

reviewText: It was a long time ago when I was much younger, but still it is a joy to see these old classic shows again. Boris Karloff wrote and acted in several of these and it was really great stuff. It was a time of black and white filming and not a lot of technical abilities for the movie industry as compared to the excellent graphic and techniques of today and yet a real pleasure to see the more simplistic approaches to filming and story telling. Great array of stories and fun to to watch.

reviewText: While you can get the 14 disc Complete Series collection of the classic horror anthology "Thriller," this assembly of fan favorites gives you an opportunity to sample ten episodes of the series without the financial burden.  The series, hosted by Boris Karloff (who also appeared in a handful of shows), ran from 1960-62 and aired a total of 67 episodes.  The program certainly shows signs of its age, but the episodes are presented remastered and uncut as they were originally showcased in the 2010 release.  "Thriller," to my mind, was one of the more successful horror series of its time and I think that it still holds up well today.Here are the episodes included.  I've included actors of interest (not necessarily the leads, but people who went on to other things) as that's part of the fun of catching these older shows.The Purple Room (Season One, Episode 7): With Richard Anderson, Rip Torn and Alan Napier.  Unscrupulous relations try to convince a man that the mansion he just inherited is haunted.The Watcher (Season One, Episode 8): With Richard Chamberlain.  After a psycho murders a teenager, he next targets a young couple.The Cheaters (Season One, Episode 15): With Harry Townes and Jack Weston, based on a Robert Bloch (Psycho) story.  A pair of eyeglasses gives the wearer an unusual gift, but it comes with a hefty price tag.The Hungry Glass (Season One, Episode 16): With William Shatner, Russell Johnson and Donna Douglas.  Ignoring ghostly tales, a young couple insist on purchasing a home by the sea.Well of Doom (Season One, Episode 23): With Richard Kiel.  A wealthy man is held captive by a powerful sorcerer and his faithful minion.The Prisoner in the Mirror (Season One, Episode 34): With Lloyd Bochner and Marion Ross.  Another sorcerer!  This one escapes from a mirror, trades bodies with a historian, and causes plenty of trouble.Pigeons from Hell (Season One, Episode 36): With Brandon DeWilde.  Two brothers with car trouble spend a terrifying night in what they think is an abandoned Louisiana mansion.The Grim Reaper (Season One, Episode 37): With William Shatner (again) and Natalie Schafer, another one by Robert Bloch.  A cursed painting may spell doom for those that possess it.The Weird Tailor (Season Two, Episode 4): With Henry Jones and George Macready, another by Bloch.  Trying to awaken his son from death, a man commissions an odd suit of clothing.The Incredible Dr. Markesan (Season Two, Episode 22): With Boris Karloff and Dick York. A young couple is forced to stay with a creepy uncle, dark secrets are revealed.These ten episodes on 2 discs is a fun way to introduce or reintroduce yourself to this classic.  KGHarris, 6/12.
summary: Ten Episodes From The Classic Horror Anthology: Alternately Scary, Cheesy, And/Or Delightfully Over-The-Top

reviewText: I chose this ten episode set rather than the entire series set because I like some of the episodes of this series, but alot of them I don't care for (the "gothic" ones aren't my cup of tea, I prefer the modern day plots). It was more affordable for me as well.I love seeing the show without commercials! I used to watch it on Sci-Fi channel, and there were so many ads it wasn't worth it.In my opinion, the best episodes on this set are "The Hungry Glass", "The Purple Room", "The Cheaters". I haven't actually finished watching all of it yet.Boris Karloff does a nice job, the casts are good, and I love black and white 60's shows, with the old cars and old Hollywood!

reviewText: I happened upon this while browsing Amazon's horror movies and immediately put it on my wish list.  Then I started reading the reviews.....  I rented the full set when it came out, and I vaguely remember audio problems(it's been a while).  It seems to be a major issue with this edition, which is enough to turn me off about the whole thing, especially since I'm hard of hearing and there are no subtitles or captions.  But what's really soured me on it is the fact that the disk is missing maybe the most famous episode in the series, A Wig for Miss Devore.  It's got everything Thriller should have had all the time:  sardonic dialogue (Natalie Shaefer in The Grim Reaper), gruesome make-up (Pigeons from Hell, The Cheaters, etc.), and, best of all, Patricia Barry.  She did a lot of TV work in the 60s (she even showed up in the It's a Good Day episode of the Twilight Zone movie!), but I mainly remember her from Thriller.  She was in The Cheaters, but in Miss Devore, she's the star.  I don't know who considers the Richard Kiley episode a "favorite,"  but I'm sure any real fan would definitely put Miss Devore on the list.
Title: N/A

reviewText: I would have loved to get the complete series, but at the current cost I just couldn't  bring myself to pay that much. The complete series is awesome, but this Fan Favorites version is a great chance to own at least a nice selections of the classic series. Being a huge Robert E. Howard fan it was very happy to see Pigeons from hell was chosen as a fan favorite though not surprised Robert E. Howard has always been a under appretiated writer being most noted for a character he created { Conan} that strayed far from the original character becoming a white washed comic book version instead of the clever survivalist barbarian he was written as. It is nice to see a work of R.E.H.'s  horror put on screen. At the reduced cost these 10 episodes are definatly worth buying. The episodes chosen for inclusion show quite well what the complete series was all about & if the price comes down I will be getting the complete series and gifting the fan favorites to my friend who is also a big R.E.H. fan
summary: A great option instead of complete series

reviewText: It's sad to think that an entire generation has grown up with no clue as to what horror really means. Today's youth thinks of horror as either serial killers with personality or ghostly encounters done with a hand held camera. They know so little of the origins of horror on film. Not only that, what was considered scary and horror filled years ago they see as quaint and funny. I've told people before, place yourself in the time period of the movie/show you're watching. Put yourself in that year. And then watch it with the eyes of someone from that time. If you choose to do so, you'll find yourself enjoying one of the classic horror anthology series from the sixties, THRILLER.You'll not only get a great show, you'll be exposed to a host whose name at one time was synonymous with horror, Boris Karloff. Here again, today's youth have no clue who Karloff, Lugosi or Chaney were which is sad indeed. Their films have been released on DVD and a new collection of horror classics is on its way to blu-ray from Universal Studios. Karloff as the host of this series presents himself well and is a good jumping on point for true fans of horror.THRILLER was one of the first shows of its kind, an anthology show that featured chilling tales each week with a different set of actors and stories. Subjects could range from tried and true mysteries to ghost stories. You never knew what you would find when you tuned in with the exception of Boris Karloff at his best, introducing that nights fright.So why talk about this series now? Last year the entire series was released by Image and is on sale now at amazon.com for $88.99. That figure can be pretty steep for someone not sure yet if this is something they'll like. So Image has released a special edition of the show, THRILLER: FAN FAVORITES which amazon offers for only $13.64. What they've done is taken 10 episodes that the fans have chosen as the best the series has to offer and collected them into an affordable box set. And some of these shows can still give you chills. What better way to start off October, the month of Halloween?One of the best leads off disc one, a story called "The Grim Reaper". In this tale a young William Shatner plays an accountant who goes to visit his aunt (GILLIGAN'S ISLAND star Natalie Shaeffer). A mystery writer who's just married a much younger man, she lives in a recently purchased house that's decorated to suit the style of her writing. To cap it off, she's purchased an infamous painting called The Grim Reaper, a painting whose owners have all died mysterious deaths. Against the warnings of her nephew, she intends to keep the painting. But things will happen before the end of this night.Another episode has a most unusual title but still offers a few scares. "Pigeon's From Hell" was based on the short story by Robert Howard, the creator of Conan the barbarian. In this story two brothers find themselves stranded while on a road trip in the south. Staying in an abandoned house, one is murdered and attempts to kill his brother. When the sheriff goes back with him, the true terror of this house is eventually revealed.These are just two examples of the sort of stories found in this collection. Topics range from haunted houses to sorcerers to ghosts to a serial killer. Better than that the talent this series offered behind the scenes was high class as well. Even PSYCHO author Robert Bloch has a tale represented here, one that was later used in the anthology film ASYLUM. And with each episode we are introduced by our benevolent host, that master of monsters known as Boris Karloff.It's sad to think that there are no shows like this any longer. For many we grew up with these as staples on TV. There was THE TWILIGHT ZONE, NIGHT GALLERY, ONE STEP BEYOND and of course THRILLER. The shows never gave us the same characters from week to week, but it did give us more scares than we bargained for. Who knows, some of these many might find scary still. But none of the scares are so far gone that even the youngest member of your family can't handle it. This show was creepy for sure, but stemming from the sixties chances are you young ones can even handle it.So if you're looking for something different this Halloween season why not give this one a try? Sit back, popcorn bowl nearby (not in hand so you won't toss it when you scare), drink on the coffee table and the light turned out. Pop in the first disc and enjoy the first 5 episodes collected here in THRILLER: FAN FAVORITES. Who knows, you might just enjoy it so much you'll save and order that entire series after all...if you dare.

reviewText: "Thriller: Fan Favorites" wisely culls the dross from sixty-seven episodes of this early 60's series and presents the ten 'best' episodes.  "Thriller" was unique for its time in that it featured gothic horror stories, unlike "The Twilight Zone" which concentrated on science fiction."Thriller" was intense enough that my parents forbade me from watching the original airings.  However, I did manage to circumvent the rules on occasion, and I did get to see "The Grim Reaper", one of the most sensational episodes of the series.  That episode, along with the legendary "Pigeons From Hell", is first in line in this compilation.There are a lot of familiar and beloved 'Boomer' icons acting in these episodes:  William Shatner (two episodes worth!), Donna Douglas ("Beverly Hillbillies"), Marion Ross ("Happy Days"), Brandon De Wilde ("Shane", "Hud"), Torin Thatcher ("7th Voyage of Sinbad"), and Richard Kiel ("Jaws" in "The Spy Who Loved Me").Some of the episodes have weathered well and still provide a few chills, including the aforementioned "Pigeons From Hell" and "The Grim Reaper".  "The Incredible Doktor Markesan" is also unique as one of the first TV forays into H.P. Lovecraft territory--although it was actually authored by his acolyte August Derleth.Now, decades along, it is also possible to appreciate the underlying humor that "Thriller" writers managed to sneak into the episodes.  In "The Well of Doom", a man is kidnapped and subjected to a medieval torture scenario, when he was just trying to get to...A STAG PARTY.  "The Hungry Glass" features a couple of barely concealed dirty jokes coming from the mouths of a 'liberated' young married couple.  And in "The Prisoner in the Mirror", there is the guilty pleasure of watching Lloyd Bochner toast Marion Ross by saying, "Happy Days!"--a decade before she was playing Ritchie Cunningham's mom.  "The Watcher" is fairly bold in revealing the story of a man who murders because of a sexual paraphilia."Thriller" must have boasted a large budget for dry ice and fake cobwebs, because there are hoary old mansions galore.  But these "spook stories" are still a kick to watch, especially when they are shot in wonderfully "noir" black and white... greatly adding to the atmosphere, and separating "Thriller" from lesser fare like "The Night Gallery" (shot in color in the 70's).

reviewText: Not all Thriller episodes were great.  The cost of the complete set was too high.  Who ever decided to make Fan Favorites available struck gold.  Two of the best horror stories I've ever seen in my life are on this set- Pigeons From Hell and The Hungry Glass.  Scared me in 1961 age 15- scared me again 2013 age 67.  Scared my 9 year old son too.  How much was it?  $13.95?  A bargain!  Amazon comes through- again!  Watch these stories at night with the lights out-  if you dare!
summary: Watch this at night with the lights out!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
Title: N/A

reviewText: Terror without sophisticated computer graphics. This collection is a sample of the old way of scaring people. Nothing fancy. Dim lighting; shades of black, white, gray; warning sounds; facial expressions. Cold drama; simple plot, eerie, creepy, weird, strange, spooky, bizarre. What I didn't see was just as frightening as what I did see. My imagination was allowed to run wild until the final conclusion. Don't believe what you see! Don't look at what's behind you! Don't look at what's in front of you! Ignore what you think you heard or don't hear! Of course some of it was predictable, but still fun to watch. Maybe Image Entertainment will issue more "Fan Favorites or a "Best Of"; because the price of the full collection is scaring me away!
Title: N/A

reviewText: I have the complete set but ordered this set because I was hoping that the audio might be less loud but it's the same.  The episode selection was more straightforward which was an improvement.  I agree with the episode selection with the exception of "The Watcher".  It should be in the worst ten.  Horror content is minimal and the suspense only lasts for a few opening seconds when the murderer is revealed and the motive as well shortly afterward.  In other words, it was a filler, not a thriller.  There are plenty of episodes that would have been better like "The Closed Cabinet".  Maybe it was a mistake and "The Hollow Watcher" was the intended episode.  It could be the first horror program that introduced a haunted scarecrow.
summary: 9 Great Episodes and 1 Less Than Average
Title: N/A

reviewText: There have been periods of magical television: Twilight Zone, Playhouse 90, Outer Limits, Picket Fences, West Wing, Honeymooners, choose your favorites. One of mine back in the early 60's was Thriller, hosted by, and occasionally starring, the arch and brilliant tones of Boris Karloff. He's always been a favorite, perhaps because under the terror was a palpably kind and gentle man with whom we could walk the paths of our terrors in good company. Here is a compilation of some favorite episodes, listed in other comments. For those of us who were there, it's a treat of the first order and a bargain at the price. Highly and affectionately recommended to all who love vintage terror (Karloff never called it "horror," which he equated with disgust). Enjoy!

reviewText: When I was 7 years old, I watched a scary show on TV with a babysitter. I couldn't remember much about it, only that it involved a car breaking down and 2 young men going to a creepy house where someone named Eula Lee lived. I remember being terrified, and all my life I tried to find out what it was. Now, 40 years later, I learned that it was an episode of THRILLER called "Pigeons From Hell," so I ordered this 10-episode collection of THRILLER Fan Favorites. I watched "Pigeons" and the other 9 episodes here, and I must say, they're pretty scary!I love THE TWILIGHT ZONE and THE OUTER LIMITS and especially ALFRED HITCHCOCK PRESENTS, but I'm only now discovering THRILLER. Boris Karloff is the host, and he's wonderful. The stories are definitely weird, and a couple of them ("Pigeons" and "The Incredible Dr. Markesan") are truly nightmarish--even scarier than those other scary series from the 1950s and 1960s. Based on these 10 episodes, I'm ready to invest in the whole series box set. I have a lot of catching up to do! If you like those other shows, you'll probably like THRILLER, too. Recommended.

reviewText: This is part of the larger series but this one has about eight different stories as well. It was a TV series that featured Boris doing the introduction. Beautiful transfer from kinescope to DVD. When you start watching them, you won't be able to stop until you watch all of them. No commercial ads just the logo between, where there used to be commercials. And Boris is featured in one of them, as we liked to see him. The young, great, Brandon de Wilde is featured in one of them too. Available here on Amazon. This series is comparable to TALES FROM THE CRYPT.
